PART I.</br>EUPHROSYNE OR JOY.</br>Laughter-loving, ruddy Fair!</br>Foe to thought and Pining care;</br>Let me pass the day with thee,</br>All in wit and mirth and glee,</br>Festive dance and revelry,</br>Wanton jokes and jollity.</br>Charm'd by thee I now disdain</br>Contemplation's leaden train,</br>Solemn, pensive, and severe,</br>Dark of mind, of brow austere.</br>Hence I leave the hoary sage,</br>Moping o'er his peevish page;</br>Mammon's drudges, griping, old,</br>Digging, starving, still for gold;</br>Full of labour, full of care,</br>Haply for base, thankless heir.</br>Lead me, Goddess!  from the cells,</br>Where pale Melancholy dwells;</br>From her dull, terrific shades,</br>Rugged rocks and gloomy glades.</br>Lead me to the lillied lawn,</br>Where thou lov'st, at early dawn,</br>Gladsome to salute the morn,</br>Of the Ocean newly born:—</br>Where, disporting ever gay,</br>All the live-long summer day,</br>With the cheerful nymphs and swains,</br>Tenants of the verdant plains;</br>Thou presidest o'er the throng,</br>Still awak'st anew the song.</br>Where the shepherds meet at eve,</br>And the toils of day relieve;</br>There thou lead'st the festive train,</br>Frisking to thy lively strain.

Glancing through the neighbouring brake,</br>Dapper elves their ditties wake;</br>Rich in gold and gems array'd,</br>Far emblazing all the shade.</br>Now they part, and now they join,</br>Now they form the starry line,</br>Instant in the circle meet,</br>Tripping light with flying feet.</br>Now in myriads mounting high,</br>Quick they sweep the dewy sky.</br>Now they seek the haunted stream,</br>Sliding down the lunar beam.

When stern winter rules the year,</br>Then to cities throng'd we steer,</br>Mix among the jovial crew</br>Plung'd in pleasures ever new.</br>There we join the midnight-choir,</br>Of thy purpled jolly Sire</br>Laughing o'er the flowing bowl,</br>That revives the sadden'd soul,</br>Warms the close and cautious heart,</br>All its secret cares t' impart;</br>Banishes reflection, sorrow,</br>And ill presage of to-morrow.</br>Thus thy votaries life enjoy,</br>Conscience, fear, and thought destroy;</br>Thus improv'd their moments fly,</br>Thus they sport and drink and — die.

PART II.</br>MELPOMENE OR MELANCHOLY.</br>Hail Melancholy!  Power divine!</br>May I approach thy awful shrine;</br>Hung round with shrouds of raven-hue,</br>Deep shaded with the mournful yew;</br>Where glimmering taper, 'mid the gloom,</br>Faint shews the frequent, heaving tomb.</br>There thou reclin'st in musing mood,</br>Thy visage veil'd in sable hood,</br>Indulging still thy doleful theme,</br>Contemplated in sad extreme,</br>Of man, degenerate, born to woe;</br>Unequal chance and change below,</br>Where Virtue oft is doom'd to groan,</br>Where prosperous Vice insults her moan.</br>There, Goddess!  there are truths approv'd,</br>By there each generous breast is mov'd;</br>There claim our tears, our serious care,</br>Thy sorrows then I beg to share.</br>—Away!  ye idle brood of Joy,</br>That all the powers of mind destroy!</br>Ye trifling toys of thoughtless youth,</br>That cheat the heart, disguise the truth!</br>Ye creatures of the giddy brain,</br>Your luring glare, I hence disdain!</br>Far from the noisy haunts of Folly,</br>Be mine thy converse, Melancholy!</br>To sit with thee in inmost bower,</br>In deepest vault of ruin'd tower,</br>Remote amid the forest wild,</br>Where day's effulgence never smil'd;</br>Whose pavement oft has drunk the gore</br>Of murder'd kings and chiefs of yore;</br>Where shrieking ghosts yet oft complain,</br>And drag a length of clanking chain.</br>Still more the sons of day affright,</br>Than all the wailing Shades of night:</br>More dark and dangerous is man,</br>Than legions squar'd of spectres wan.</br>Hence worn with care, inur'd to grief,</br>Despairing still of kind relief,</br>I leave at length a world of woe,</br>Its empty pleasures all forego;</br>To thee my future hours devote,</br>Indulging strains of saddest note.</br>Hence let me shun the glare of day,</br>Till Midnight rise in black array,</br>Till through the silent, dusky grove,</br>Uninterrupted I may rove.</br>Nor wish I mortal footing near,</br>Nor other sound desire to hear,</br>Save Philomela's nightly wail,</br>Slow quivering on the lonely gale;</br>Or, save the owl's discordant song,</br>That scatters dread the woods among,</br>Responsive to the sullen wave,</br>Hoarse dashing through the shelved cave.</br>The gelid spring and acorns plain,</br>Shall still my meagre corps sustain.</br>Upon the cold and craggy steep</br>I throw my naked length to sleep;</br>Regardless of the wintry skies,</br>Regardless though I ne'er arise.
PART III.</br>SOPHRONIA OR SERENITY.</br>Complacent Nymph!  of mildest mien,</br>Image of the soul serene;</br>With heavy heart inur'd to woe,</br>At thy sacred shrine I bow.

Deceiv'd by false licentious Joy,</br>Sailing, luring to destroy,</br>On waxen wing of Hope I flew,</br>Charm'd, from far her form to view.</br>From scene to scene she shifted, smil'd,</br>Still allur'd, and still beguil'd;</br>At length the prov'd a fury fell,</br>Plunged me in the dismal cell,</br>Where Melancholy's vot'ries stare</br>Wild on hopeless, dark Despair.</br>—"Thus all must fare, the Goddess said,</br>Who are by the syren led.</br>Before the eyes of heedless youth,</br>Blind, averse to see the truth,</br>Her fatal charms she fair displays,</br>Till, bewilder'd in her maze,</br>Aghast they see her meteor-light</br>Sudden drown'd in blackest night.</br>Wrong'd conscience wakes, and Terror scowls,</br>Loud the lonely desart howls.</br>Thus disappointed, thus forlorn,</br>Solitary left to mourn,</br>Affliction's tempest roaring round,</br>All the soul unpois'd, unsound;</br>How sad, how comfortless their state,</br>Toss'd the sport of adverse Fate!</br>More hapless they who run direct,</br>Guilty pleasure's course uncheck'd;</br>Till Death, now deem'd afar to stand,</br>Seize them with resistless hand.

From Passion's source is found to flow</br>Each severer mortal woe.</br>How wretched those who must obey,</br>While it rules with sovereign sway!</br>Undisciplin'd in early age,</br>Soon it rises into rage,</br>Disdaining Reason's due control,</br>Fierce convulsing, all the soul;</br>Impatient of the talk design'd</br>To improve and fit the mind,</br>By steady duty, trying care,</br>Virtue's high reward to share.

To bask in joy's unclouded ray,</br>Ever thoughtless, ever gay,</br>Befits not mortals born to woe,</br>In this tearful vale below.</br>Yet not in Melancholy's cell</br>Are they ever doom'd to dwell.</br>Her darker day they ne'er may prove,</br>While in Virtue's path they move,</br>Unsway'd by treacherous Pleasure's smile,</br>Harbouring anguish, guilt and guile.

While Mind from conscious crimes is clear,</br>Then may Fortune's tempest drear</br>Infuriate blacken all the sky;—</br>Then it dares its rage defy,</br>Serene regards its heaven-rul'd power,</br>Patient bears th' afflicting hour;</br>Assur'd that soon the trial hard</br>Shall be crown'd with rich reward."</br>
